creator: ralph-apachebugzilla@inputplus.co.uk
text:
mod_rewrite's REQUEST_FILENAME in a <Directory> isn't the full, requested, path.  Say root is /a and I request /b/c/d/e.  Only /a/b exists on disk, there's no c there.  %{REQUEST_FILENAME} will be /a/b/c because it stopped being built when c wasn't found.

The behaviour is understandable but is not documented AFAICS.  Attempts to match against e$ for example fail because /d/e didn't make it into REQUEST_FILENAME.

http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/mod_rewrite.html#rewritecond describes REQUEST_FILENAME.

creator: covener@gmail.com
text: Do you think it is enough to say "Affected by the value of AcceptPathInfo" in that section? Don't want to duplicate too much.

creator: ralph-apachebugzilla@inputplus.co.uk
text: How about "It may not contain all of the request's path;  see AcceptPathInfo".  That's just enough to trigger alarm bells and make the reader take the effort to follow the AcceptPathInfo link.

creator: covener@gmail.com
text: r1456061 in trunk and backported to 2.4
Thanks, has some spelling mistakes though.  "vaue" and "requet".
creator: ralph-apachebugzilla@inputplus.co.uk
